Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Highly-ordered Electrode/Catalyst Assembly in Proton Exchange Membrane Fuel Cells for Enhanced Catalyst Utilization

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
ABSTRACT

Fuel cells are seen as promising, environmentally desirable alternatives to fossil fuel powered applications, particularly for transportation. Significant investments have been made in this area, but economical fuel cells remain a target. A key factor that has limited the progress in broad deployment of fuel cell devices is the high cost of the incorporated platinum catalyst nanoparticles. In this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award, Professor Vibha Kalra of Drexel University, Philadelphia, PA will attempt to change this situation using a unique nanofiber-based catalyst layer in proton exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cells. The catalyst will be fabricated via a process called electrospinning. Electrospinning is a simple fiber formation technique that uses strong electric field to accelerate and thin a polymer solution/melt jet, resulting in fibers with nanoscale diameters (50-500 nm). The project will involve experiments and multi-scale simulations to first understand and tailor the internal assembly in the proposed catalyst layer followed by a detailed investigation of the effect of this nanoscale assembly on performance in fuel cells. The aim is to develop an intertwined network within the catalyst layer, such that the catalyst (platinum) nanoparticles have simultaneous access to all reactants for the electrochemical reaction to take place efficiently. This will maximize the electrochemical surface area and consequently the utilization of catalyst nanoparticles, thereby resulting in lower total catalyst cost.

The integrated educational objective of this project is to help students at K-12, undergraduate and graduate levels, particularly women and those from under-represented minorities, to appreciate the power of science and engineering in general and to inspire them to contribute to society through continued research in materials and renewable energy. A comprehensive K-12 outreach program will be developed by Prof. Kalra, involving workshops and research experience for students and teachers in the Philadelphia area, where currently 80% of students are minorities. The integrated educational activities will generate interest in materials and energy research among a much larger audience at various education levels.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
CAREER: Highly-ordered Electrode/Catalyst Assembly in Proton Exchange Membrane Fuel Cells for Enhanced Catalyst Utilization

 

PI: Vibha Kalra, Drexel University

 

In this project, we developed and studied binder-free, self-standing electrodes and demonstrated their benefits in both energy storage and conversion devices, particularly fuel cells and batteries.  The materials were fabricated using a scalable process called electrospinning, which enabled us to eliminate the need for binders and current collectors from the devices The elimination of binders from the developed electrodes is beneficial not only for improvement of electron transport (and therefore device performance) but also elimination of the slurry processing, a cathode fabrication step, currently used in industry that can account for up to 20% of the total electrode cost. On the other hand, current collectors can account for 30-50% of the electrode weight and successful elimination of these layers, as demonstrated in our work, can facilitate the development of lighter weight devices.  Further development can potentially enable this green technology to successfully compete in the transportation sector and achieve driving ranges comparable to that of gasoline-operated vehicles at comparable cost.


Intellectual Merit

This work has resulted in 14 peer-reviewed journal articles and several conference presentations

#Undergraduate Author

  1. Chau Tran; Kalra, Vibha.  Soft Matter, v.9, 2013, p. 846-852.
  2. Chau Tran; Kalra, Vibha. Journal of Power Sources, v.235, 2013, p. 289-296.
  3. Tran, Chau and Kalra, Vibha. J. Chem. Phys., v.140, 2014, p. 134902.
  4. Singhal, R.; Chung, S-H.; Manthiram, A.; Kalra, V. Journal of Materials Chemistry A, v.3, 2015, p. 4530.
  5. Singhal, R.; Kalra, V. Journal of Materials Chemistry A, v.3, 2015, p. 377.
  6. Tran, C.; Singhal, R.; Lawrence, D.#; Kalra, V. Journal of Power Sources, v.293, 2015, p. 373.
  7. Lawrence, D.W.#, Tran, C., Mallajoysula, A.T., Doorn, S.K., Mohite, A., Gupta, G., Kalra, V. Journal of Materials Chemistry A, v.4, 2016, p. 160.
  8. Simotwo, S.K., DelRe, C.#, Kalra, V. ACS Applied Materials and Interfaces, v.8, 2016, p. 21261.
  9. Simotwo, S.K., Kalra, V. Electrochimica Acta, v.198, 2016, p. 156.
  10. Simotwo, S.K., Kalra, V.. Current Opinion in Chemical Engineering, v.13, 2016, p. 150.
  11. Tran, C; Lawrence, D.#; Richey, FW; Dillard, C. Elabd, YA; Kalra, V., Chemical Communications, v.51, 2015, p. 13760.
  12. Simotwo, S.; Chinnam, PR.; Wunder, S. L.; Kalra, V. ACS Applied Materials and Interfaces, v.9, 2017, p. 33749.
  13. Simotwo, S.; Kalra, V.  Electrochimica Acta, v.268, 2018, p. 131.
  14. Singh, A. and Kalra, V., v.10, 2018, 37937.

Summary of Results

In this work, we integrated experiments and molecular dynamics simulations to study the morphology and kinetics of phase separation in immiscible binary mixtures under elongational flow, with particular focus on polymer blends. Our interest in studying this system under elongational flow arises from our experimental work on electrospinning, a simple fiber formation technique that uses strong electric field to elongate a polymer solution or melt jet forming ultra-thin nanofibers. Our work revealed that the elongational flow during electrospinning significantly impacted the morphology of a phase separating polymer blend and allowed us to achieve nanoscale assembly that would not be possible in equilibrium conditions. The nanoscale assembly of electron conducting polymer and Nafion (proton conducting polymer), as studied in our experimental work enables facile transport of electrons and protons to the catalyst particles facilitating efficient reaction in proton exchange membrane fuel cells.

In addition, we report the stabilization of titanium monoxide (TiO) nanoparticles in nanofibers through electrospinning and carbothermal processes and their unique bi-functionality ? high conductivity and ability to bind intermediate polysulfides ? in Lithium-Sulfur (Li-S) batteries. Li-S are battery chemistries that exhibit a theoretical capacity (key metric that defines battery run time between charges) of 5-10 times higher than that of state-of-the-art Li-ion batteries, the batteries present in our laptops, cell phones and electric cars. However, commercialization of Li-S batteries is plagued by dissolution of intermediate reaction products (polysulfides) in the electrolyte leading to loss of active material and loss of capacity with each charge-discharge cycle. The developed TiO/S cathodes in this work induce strong interactions with these intermediate products mitigating this loss. The developed TiO/CNF-S cathodes exhibit high initial discharge capacities of ~1080 mAh g-1, 5-fold higher than that of Li-ion batteries, with significant capacity retention with long-term cycling.

 

Broader Impact

This project involved several undergraduate and 3 PhD students from the PI?s research group. It provided all the students involved with inter-disciplinary experience in nanomaterials and alternate energy along with an opportunities to enhance their presentation and technical writing skills via several conference and group meeting presentations and paper and report writing. Moreover, this work resulted in four peer- reviewed publications with undergraduate students as either first authors (2/4) or co- authors (2/4).

 


Last Modified: 01/29/2020
Modified by: Vibha Kalra
